awd_titl_txt: DDRIG in DRMS: Communicating Controversial Risk Issues - Effects of Inoculation Messages on Selective Exposure to Counterattitudinal Messages and Subsequent Persuasive Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
Public communication surrounding controversial risk and policy issues is often characterized by competitive messaging, whereby different messengers compete to frame these risk issues in ways that they believe will shift public and policymaker opinions in favor of their interests. Inoculation is a long-standing persuasion theory that describes framing and responses to risk issues. Prior research suggests that inoculation messages can confer resistance to persuasion by another competing message. This study expands inoculation theory by testing people’s tendency to approach or avoid competing messages after being inoculated. If an inoculation message makes people more likely to proactively seek out competing information, they might be susceptible to persuasion from competing information compared to other messaging strategies that do not encourage people to explore competing information. This research tests and extends inoculation theory with the goal of helping risk communicators and policymakers to better understand how people process messages characterized by competition and controversy. 

In examining inoculation theory, the researchers are studying two issues that are characterized by competition and controversy – gun violence and nuclear energy. This research (N = 1,500) features a 2 (persuasive strategy – inoculation vs. one-sided) by 2 (issue direction – pro or con) by 2 (preexisting attitude direction – pro or con) between-subject experimental design, plus an offset control condition. It tests how people who read an inoculation message differ from other people in their selective exposure to counter messages or attack messages and subsequent persuasive outcomes. It further explores how these effects may differ among people whose initial attitudinal position is either consistent or inconsistent with the inoculation message advocated position. This research offers risk communicators theory-informed guidance on how to better employ an inoculation strategy to communicate with audiences in today’s high-choice media environment. Findings also shed light on the effects of risk messages among members of the public who hold a wide range of preexisting issue positions for controversial risk issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Public communication surrounding controversial risk and policy issues is often characterized by competitive messaging, whereby different messengers compete to frame these issues in ways that they believe will shift public and policymaker opinions in favor of their interests. Inoculation is a long-standing persuasion theory that describes framing and responses to various topics, and research suggests that inoculation messages can confer resistance to oppositional persuasion. This dissertation sought to expand understanding of inoculation theory by testing people’s tendency to approach or avoid competing messages after being inoculated. If an inoculation message makes people more likely to proactively seek out competing information (a plausible outcome suggested by several recent studies), they might be susceptible to persuasion by virtue of exposure to a larger volume of competing information compared to other messaging strategies that do not encourage people to explore competing information.

Studies 1 and 2 served as pilot tests, examining the effects of inoculation messages on people’s selective exposure to counter-attitudinal messages and subsequent persuasive outcomes in the context of gun laws. It further explored how these effects differed among people whose initial attitudinal position was either consistent or inconsistent with the position advocated by the inoculation message. Study 3 replicated the initial experiment to test the robustness of its findings. Studies 4 and 5 pretested constructs and stimuli that were used in the final experiment. Study 6 (data collection funded by this current NSF grant), the final experiment, tested hypotheses regarding the impact of inoculation on selective exposure and persuasion outcomes and expanded the contexts to include nuclear energy and enhanced ecological validity by incorporating diverse types of articles on mock webpages. In Study 1, counter-attitudinal inoculations induced strong confirmation bias and significantly shifted policy support toward the inoculation advocated position, while pro-attitudinal inoculations did not. This was not replicated in Study 3, where both pro-attitudinal and counter-attitudinal inoculations induced confirmation bias without shifting attitudes. Study 6 found varied effects depending on the issue (gun laws or nuclear energy), with a marginally significant protective effect of pro-attitudinal messages on policy support for nuclear energy, and uncovered more complex patterns of selective exposure.

Looking across the series of studies, counter-attitudinal inoculation messages (those opposing the participants’ initial attitude) effectively shifted policy support away from initial positions in Study 1 but had no significant effects in subsequent studies, indicating that external factors like recent events and issue specific attitude strength may influence results. Pro-attitudinal inoculation showed a marginal protective effect for nuclear energy in Study 6, which demonstrates that inoculation can still be useful in protecting people’s preexisting attitudes even after selective exposure. A newer mechanistic variable in inoculation, motivational threat, showed promise as an important mechanism in the inoculation process, particularly in the context of nuclear energy in Study 6. The study further suggested that inoculation messages can significantly boost the motivation to defend preexisting attitudes and counterargue future persuasive attacks.

This research offers theory-informed guidance on how strategic communicators can better employ an inoculation strategy to communicate with audiences in today’s high-choice media environment. Findings also shed light on the effects of risk messages among members of the public who hold a wide range of preexisting issue positions for controversial risk issues.

The co-PI successfully defended this dissertation at Cornell University and archived it in ProQuest in 2023, under the supervision of the PI. In 2024, the co-PI attended and presented this research at the annual conference of the International Communication Association, flagship conference in the field of Communication in in Gold Coast, Australia. It is currently in the process of revision and submission to a Communication journal. At ICA, this work received a top paper award with the highest peer-review ratings in the Information Systems Division, which was featured in “The Best of Information Systems” presentation session. This dissertation also received the prestigious Annie Lang Dissertation Award from ICA Information Systems Division, this annual award recognizes the most outstanding dissertation focusing on a topic relevant to the Division.
